UPDATED: MAR 22, 2015 (10/07/2011) [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ beertasting  sample: dark brown with a slight red hue & a mocha head, smell very sweet with dark fruits (prominent prunes) & sweet dark malt, taste is sweet prunes, figs & green apples, dark malt, slight spices in the finish, touch of wood, caramel, light liquorice & some alcohol in the finish, best-liked beer at the beertasting ///// Split another 75 cl. 2013 Vintage after release. No notes but favourable impression. Old score kept. /////// Should take some better notes here, I certainly like it more than the 4.4/5 score suggests. ////////// (22/03/2015) 2000 Vintage bottle sampled. A bit thin but still really nice, has kept up well enough for it to still have plenty of dark fruit flavours, plenty of liquorish, touch oak & leaves. Keeping it longer will be a total waste.

Bottle. Pours a clear and dark brown beer with a small beige head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, fruit and alcohol. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness and alcoholwarmth. Overall a good beer.

Sampled from bottle at SIB, pours hazy golden caramel with a reddish hue. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar and dark fruits. Flavour of doppelbock-like fruits, caramel and complex dark fruits. Most excellent.

Bottle: Deep amber coloured, almost clear, mid-sized stable tanned head with a little lace; dried figues, walnut -oil in the nose with a slight alcoholic touch; moderate to solid swet-bitter flavour, full bodied; lingering sweet-malty finish with a solid walnutty flavour. Really good.....
Nice dark brown color with a red glare coming through. Smell not really special. Complex taste, nice carbonation.

Had this out of a bottle last year and recently on tap. Rating will be for the on tap as there was quite a difference between the two. Dark pour with small tan head. Fruity aroma with caramel and toffee coming through. Taste was sweet caramel and black licorice standing out. The main difference between the tap and bottle i found was that the bottle exhibited port like taste, probably due to aging. Interesting beer either way.
Very dark brown bear pours from the large, classy bottle. Smell and taste are a bit dull. In balance though. Could use a bit more co2/body in the mouthfeel.
Tap @ The BeerMongers...  Poured dark brown with a tan head.  Little bit of diacetyl on the nose.  Dark fruits, raisins and dates.  Malty with a strong amount of alcohol heat with some yeast spice.

2009 vintage. Huge pour into thin goblet. 2" head lattices down to seafoam. The aroma is effusive; it escapes the glass and finds you: notes of candy, doppelbock-meets-quadrupel, alcohol-soaked-dark-fruit. Some red wine grapes. On taste, this beer shows almost indescribable complexity. This is like drinking a fine port: a sweet, after-dinner, sipping beverage. And in fact, the flavors are surprisingly reminiscent of port. Sweet red wine notes and richness hit in the finish. An altogether unique beer of amazing depth. Belgium has done it again.

Bottle at the Mondial de la Bieres. Clear amber pour with a brown hint. Little tan head and almost no lace. Candied prunes, licorice and mint on the nose. Quite heavy on the palate with a fairly intense sweetness. Finishes with a bittersweet mint feel. Interesting.
great beer.  pours a dark brown, cola like with a light head.  cherries, raisins, dark fruity smell.  rich in malts.  some alcohol warming.  very good stuff.  great find at Costco.

Bottle from 2009. Pours dark muddy brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is of resin and syrup from tons of fruits/malts - raisins, caramel, plums, burnt sugar. Flavor is mostly of raisins and alcohol with some notes of grapes, caramel malts, and burnt sugar. A tad too boozy for my tastes, but not too awful considering the ABV.
Bottle at work. Dark brown colour with a dense off-white head. Aroma and flavour of spice, dark dried fruit, yeast, chocolate malt and caramel.

Bottle, Aroma of plums, raisins and alcohol. Dark and clear red colour with beige head. Sweet and elegant flavour of ripe fruits, raisins, malt and brown sugar. Soft mouthfeeling and long lasting sweet aftertaste.

Reddish mahogany with a small, creamy, off-white head that doesnt retain very well. Splotchy lacing. Caramel, toffee, plum, raisin, yeast, and alcohol in the aroma. Similar flavor, mostly sweet, with some bitterness and warmth on the finish. Medium viscosity with soft, pleasant carbonation. Tasty.

(bottle, 75cl, vintage 2008) Almost clear, dark brown colour with a beige medium-sized foamy head. Sweet and slightly roasted malty and nutty aroma with with a slightly vinous dried fruity touch. Sweet and slightly roasty bitter flavour, full bodied with a moderate carbonation. Dark malty and (hazel-)nutty taste with dried figs, hints of chocolate and ethereally spicy notes; sweet dark malty and dried fruity finish with a discreet roasty bitterness in aftertaste. Pleasant. 18.V.11
Dark brown and a little watery. Red fruit, cane sugar, pecan and pine. Full of sweet delicate flavour. Little too watery for me but a nice sweet spicyness.  (75cl bottle)

Bottle @ home. Dark brown appearance with a tan head. Belgian yeast, caramel, candy sugar, dark malty nose. Caramel, strong candy sugar, slightly boozy, slightly thick and syrupy flavor. Syrupy, candy sugar finish. Thick candy sugar aftertaste. I cant believe its taken me seven years to finally taste this beer. It really reminds me of a Quadrupel thats very sweet and mildly boozy.

15/05/2011 75cl bottle @ Brouwerij Het Anker (2011-209) 
Cloudy murky brown beer, light beige creamy had, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: dries fruits, alcohol, caramel, overripe fruits, red berries. MF: soft carbon, full body, a bit syrupy texture. Taste: a lot of spices, lots of caramel, dried fruits, a bit of brown sugar, cloves and anise. Aftertaste: sweet, a bit bitter, still lots of spices playing. Very complex and interesting brew. I could finish a bottle of this on my own. Easy.

Bottle 2007, courtesy of peermac.Pours deep amber with a tiny off-white head.Aroma dried raisins, prunes, alcohol, caramelized apples and spicy malt.Flavor is sweet and warming with some notes of apples and caramel.Medium to full body, average carbonation.Nice classic Belgian ale.

Bottle 750ml vintage 2007 @ Geokkjer
[Courtesy of Peermac] Pours reddish brown with almost no head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, raisin, prunes, alcohol, dried fruits and chocolate. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat.

Bottle.  Pours very dark with a small, dense off-white head.  Aroma and flavor are boozy, brandied dark cherries, caramel, vanilla, earthy yeast.  Has some typical Belgian notes (yeast, spices, etc.), but they are subdued.  Thick mouthfeel.  A great beer to savor.  Thanks, Dave!

Charles V was one of the great monsters in history.  He presided over several wars in Europe, imprisoned the Pope, and profited from the destruction of the Aztec empire and its people.  This beer is every bit the monster that its namesake was.  Even though the American craft/boutique brewers are able to match the flavor of this style with chemistry and biology, they have never been able to match the texture and body that the closely guarded techniques of the Belgian master brewers at Gouden Carolus had mastered 500 years ago.  The perfect beer.

Shared bottle at tasting with Ryan, ScottyP, and thanks to John. Packaging looks fine but the beer itself looks nasty. Its a very visually heterogeneous beer. Brown orangery globules float not just at the bottom of the glass but throughout the beer. This was the 2nd pour too, so it wasnt like I was getting the dregs. The beer smells and tastes great though. Im not blown away, but the this beer tastes and smells great. The palate is a chunky. Maybe the sight of the beer is messing with my head. Not something I would seek out, but darn good. Could probably age forever as well.

750mL corked and caged bottle from 2010.  This pours dark red and clear with tinges of orange on the edges, very lively and effervescent, with  a foamy and creamy 2-finger tan head composed of super-fine bubbles.  The aromas are sweet Belgian yeast and bubblegum, raisin, oak, alcohol, some plum and cherry, sugar, and perhaps some caramel and cocoa.  The flavor is sweet candied apples and plums, cherry and raisin, and caramel with a sweet yeast finish alongside slight alcohol.  The finish is bitter grass and fruit stones.  This has moderate carbonation and full body, lending to a creamy mouthfeel with a slightly warming quality.  Very nice, with well-hidden alcohol.  A very tasty beer; sweet, silky, and delicious. [659]
Bottle @ DØA Randers. Dark reddish brown with a pale brown head. Aroma of dark fruit, candy and plum. Very sweet with a little sprite end.

Bottle from Mane Liquor, has been aged for about 1 year. Pours a deep brown with a medium, foamy beige head. Aroma is smooth nuts and chocolate. Gentle light vanilla backs this up. Flavour brings out a sweet backing of caramel malts and sweet honey. Much sweeter than first anticipated. Very complex taste. Almost sour in the like of dark cherries. Good beer but dont agree with the rating this one is getting. Might have to a have it again in another few years

2010 Version. Clear dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit, yeast and spices. Flavor is quite sweet. Full bodied, soft and smooth. This is a very well balanced and complex beer.  Excellent. 291010

Seriously?  This beer is that good?  A decent Belgian, but not that outstanding to me.  I would have never known it was supposed to be this good if not for RateBeer.  Run of the mill Belgian aroma and flavor - it even had the feel of its 11% alcohol behind it.

2009 bottle: I smell gently sweet fruit, cola notes and alcohol (damn allergies). Its mahogany brown with almost a lavender tint, and dense, lush tan foam on top. Its a nutty, sweet, syrupy mouthful of ale. Some toasted pecan-ish bitterness follows the ultra smooth biscuity, near chocolate cake flavors. Noticeable alcohol but not overwhelming considering its 11%.  Im sure this sounds all over the place, I do have some sinus issues at present, but its so complex, yet mellow. Like a chocolate cake with a brandied cherry sauce?? Wonderful and balanced, artisanal without a doubt. I say drink, contemplate, and notice some subtleties.

Thin, patchy, steady head. Deep brown sugar and raisin yeast notes. Super smooth body, creamy and rich. This beer is world class all the way, delicate and bold at the same time. Lots of dark fruit tones, perfectly balanced and complemented by the rich sugary malt tones. Deep rum soaked nut tones. Superb.

The disclaimer in the description of this beer is hilarious.  I was told to age this. Every day i come home from work and see it. Brian, you did a disservice to carolus when you gave me this beer to taste.  Before I change the oil in the shovel, I grab this.  I am not qualified to even look at this bottle. Lots of money put into this package.  Pop the cork for a gentle light vanilla aroma that lends no hand to the impact of the first taste. Big giant caramel sweet head ringing blast of toffee something that cannot be described. Strong and whiley eee kia-yotie.  A big muddy brown pour into my big beer glass. Thick cloying sweet and something! Barely any CO2 detetable in this kingly brew.  Smooth thin tan choc moose head. Must be the beer of the beer idols.  2009 version. Wew, rototilling across the back of my conscience and back agian. Over and over.   THIS BEER ROCKS....but its a little over the top for this poor lager beer lover. I think I feel a buzz, hope this wont cause a headache. After a few more slugs i think Im getting more congenial, yes congeniality, hehe.  Continuing thru the session I can honestly say this is not a session beer, except for the real men of this site.  Rude keathery full of non hiding alkohol personality....a cult of personality.  Darker, real darker, HAH.  Pacifying and annoying at the same time, dont let me rest.  IT sets youy free. Drink this with a friend, I shoulddah couldah wooddah.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
The beer pours a very carbonated mukry gold with a little honey color. The head is white very carbonated, rises about 3 fingers and has good retention and lacing. 

The aroma is light to medium a little grass, hops, and a very small amount of spice. 

The taste is awesome, it starts out smooth with a light sweet start, then fades to some complexity with some light hops, and finishes with a little hops. This is what a light beer should taste like. Easy to drink, tons of flavor and filling.

The feel is nice and incredible drinkability.

Overall, this beer is excellent. I would consider this best session beer ever because of its drinkability, and with abv itll get your cracked twice as quick.

Bouteille de 750ml. Cuvée-Jaargang 2010. La bière est brune avec des reflets rouges. La mousse était absente dans ma coupe Gouden Carolus, mais il en avait un peu dans le verre Belle Gueule. Le nez est invitant, agréable, dans un registre malté, de fruits secs, figues. En bouche cette bière est du velours, elle enrobe la langue, lalcool est chaleureux mais jamais agressant. Les goûts de sucre dorge, de toffee, de pain dorée, danis et une multitude de saveurs sont dune incroyable richesse. Le corps de cette bière est exemplaire. Difficile de faire mieux, nous sommes dans une classe à part. 9/10 Merci Patrick, un gros merci.

2010 bottle. Aroma of ripe pear, honey, some sulphur, alcohol. Sticky, soft to average carbonation. Very sweet, ripe fruits, complex taste, a little sourness in the aftertaste. Would have enjoyed it more if hopped a little heavier. Not balanced well enough to be truly amazing but very good nonetheless.

Very strong aroma, caramel-like, roasted. Thick, whitish brown head. Dark amber in appearance. Taste is like the aroma, heavy, slight sweetness in the aftertaste. Mild hops. A little bit of carbonation. Delicious beer.

Le liquide dévoile une robe brune qui, une fois illuminée, se drape de reflets rouges.  La tête mousseuse formée reste en place quelques secondes pour se transformer en anneau.  De toutes petites pointes de dentelles dessinent un incroyable relief.  Les arômes de cette divine concoction exhibent une incroyable richesse.  Les malts sont gras de caramel et de bonbon chocolaté.  Les parfums fruités sont chauds et dégoulinants de raisins, de prunes et de cerises.  Quelques pointes de sucre candi rencontrent des souffles de friandises anisées.  Des épices se perdent dans un alcool de grand cru qui cherche à sévaporer en fleurs délicieuses.  Au goût, les saveurs sont tout aussi spectaculaires, alliant des pointes timides de rhum avec une base maltée gargantuesque et fortement réconfortée par des fruits mûrs et macérés dans un alcool qui nest jamais brûlant ni décapent mais envoûtant et insidieux.  En bouche, le liquide a une structure forte, bien charpenté, ronde à souhait, expansive.  Son effervescence me semble parfaite, maîtrisée, capable de fouetter la grande suavité de son corps.  La texture du liquide est dangereusement riche, crémeuse, caressante, très satinée.  La finale est liquoreuse en goût par ses fruits et en force par son intelligence éthylique ardente et voluptueuse.  En résumé, is this a beer or a piece of paradise?

2009 Bottle.  Pours reddish brown with nice head that quickly dropped to a trace.  Aroma is dark fruits, earthyness and caramel.  Taste is sweet with the dark fruits adding an acidic bite.  Creamy mouthfeel.  An excellent brew.

750ml corked and caged bottle.  Pours a deep, murky, stained-glass red-brown.  Thin, patchy, steady head.  Deep brown sugar and raisin yeast notes.  Super smooth body, creamy and rich.  This beer is world class all the way, delicate and bold at the same time.  Lots of dark fruit tones, perfectly balanced and complemented by the rich sugary malt tones.  Deep rum soaked nut tones.  Superb.  Quite mellow despite the big ABV.
Very excellent dark strong ale. Each year, this beer is a little different... but always awesome.

Had at belgian cafe. Pour was a nice deer berry with little head. Aroma is full of berries and sweet malts. Flavor is curry and malts with a nice balance of caramel. Really well balanced and delicious.
Sweet and decadent, especially on tap. This is one of the top Strong Darks out there, thick and decadent.
Im transferring ratings from another beer app to this one. My tasting notes wouldnt be accurate at this point since they werent captured at the time.
Bottle 0,75ltr: Dark brown coloured brew with an red glow, good dried fruits, caramel and spices taste, and some warm feeling in the mouth.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 I had it from 2000, 2008, 2009 and 2010.
have another bottle from 2005 and 2 from 2000 in my cellar.

Heavy beer, complex aromas chocolate, caramel, alcohol, cough drop, licorice, raisin, soy sauce, vanilla, woody.

Once a year brewed on the 24th of february

750ml bottle - 2009 reserve.
Dark brown, reddish pour with a good amount of white head.  A bit of sour cherry, liquorice, very sweet.  I would like to pick another, fresher bottle of this up to see the difference, as im told its not as sweet then.  All in all, a very tasty and decadent Belgian dark.
Great malty..roasty aroma...raisins.  Beautiful dark brown, red color.  Emperors crand cru...mmmm.  Ill add more later...

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2017 2010 bottle. Very dark red brown body with a creamy off-white head that never disappears, nice lacing too. Malty sweet aroma, blackberries, caramel, dark fruits. Full bodied, smooth, low carbonation. Complex dark, sweet flavour, a bit to the sour side, spicy long lasting finish. (9/5/9/5/19)
2016 bottle. Very dark red body with a creamy beige head. Sweet aroma with lots of caramel, cherry, alcoholic with plum, blackberries, brown sugar, syrup, red grapes. Perfect, smooth palate. Quite sweet flavour with caramel, sour cherries, as well as raisin, syrup, fig, sweet wine. Remarkable.

Regional Food and Drink, DC 10oz tap ($9): Got it as G.C. Grand Cru: Pours a ruby brown color with a beige head (although I cant really comment that much on it because I only saw the remnants because of the pour). Aroma is very fruity, winy, with some yeast, along with plenty of sugar. Very sweet tasting, but not cloying. Alcohol (contrary to what most people here are saying) was very well covered in my opinion. Yeasty finish methinks. Plenty of different flavors all around. Quite good methinks. Well-balanced.

2008 vintage. Poured into a snifter. Big thanks to spimptastikx for this one.

4.0 A: Clear dark amber brown color. One and a half fingers of frothy light tan head with average retention and some spotty lacing.

4.5 S: Very nice. Dark fruits with a lot of plum. Sugary cake icing. Light to moderate booziness. Touch of raisin and touch of tobacco. Peppery spiciness.

4.0 T: A ton of peppery spiciness. Way more than in the nose. Raisin and tobacco are also more prominent while the plum is less so. Moderate to high booziness this time, which is okay for 11% ABV, but not ideal.

3.5 M: Lighter medium body. This is the first time Ive ever thought this for a Belgian brew, but Id say theres too much carbonation. Im producing some formidable belches. Otherwise, the carbonation is spritzy. Boozy throughout and a little extra on the finish.

3.5 D: Good brew, but the carbonation is too high and the brew itself is a bit too boozy for this to be very drinkable. I bet this ages well.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-12-2010 02:58:00

Nose: Nice Belgian spices.
Taste: Sweet and creamy, lovely spices, caramel and brown sugar.
After taste: Long and well balanced.

on tap @McMenamins - Dark red-brown pour with light tan head that quickly vanishes.  Strong aromas of malt and sugars with a slight resiny hop aroma.  Flavor is big body, malt and candy sugars (but not overly sugary or sweet).  Strong alcohol sensation more than tastes.  Long complex finish of dried dark fruits, cherries, and raisins.

Bottle from Sams in Durham, aged 2-3 years.  Pours medium-dark chestnut brown, hazy with some sediment and a soft, small beige head.  Nose of buttery caramel, sweetened hazelnuts and chestnuts, candied sugar, and a bit of maple syrup.  Mild chocolate notes as well.  Similar taste, with the buttery caramel coming through strongly.  Some German chocolate cake action going on.  Very good.

a lovely thick belgian barley wine type beer, like ordinary gouden carolus in the emphasis on malt, but also here a bit spicy and christmasy which was good cause i drank it on christmas day with some gorgonzola. deep and malty, some nice chocolatey notes, but not much complexity - not a lot of yeast flavour or fruitiness - and unfortunately some hot vodka-like alcohol riding along the whole time. not bad but i wish i got the big bottle of st bernardus 12 for xmas day instead

2010 vintage. Dark ruby-brown beer. Creamy pale head. Sweet and fruity aroma full of dates, raisins, and creamy candi sugar. Liquid fugde with lovely fruitiness. Gets vinous and deeper, slightly chocolatey when warms up. Nice, sweetly phenolic yeast character with wine gummy fruit aromas. Full bodied, lush and very smooth texture. Sticky sugary goodness.

Notes from 09/2008. 2008 vintage.

Dark copper with hints of vermilion at the edges. Head is wonderfully creamy and full, an off-white with reddish-brown hues. This is one heck of a head; it feels great on the lips, but holds softly and fully at one finger in size.

Initial metallic aromas. I cant quite put my nose on it, but I do catch dark fruit and tobacco. Some spice.
The second pour barks orchard fruit ... is that apricot? candied peaches? an alcohol-infused fresh fruit syrup? Definite cherry. Whoa. I am very impressed with the nose as this warms. 

Alcoholic finish. Smooth. Raisins. Cherries. Dried lingonberries. Plums. Orange. Caramel malts. Sugar and spice. Sugar, then spice. 

Mouthcoating. Have I said creamy? Medium-full with good carbonation. 

A great sipper or sharer. Only drawback - for some - might be the unmasked alcohol. Perhaps not for the faint of heart, but Cuvee Van De Keizer is no feint, nevertheless. This is one solid, beautiful BDSA.
awesome beer and if you drink the whole bottle your self ull be srt for awhile!! sweet but dark flavors sweet finsishgreat color dark hazy and biege head i wish i had more

Courtesy of Roger Wilcox Deptford, NJ. Pours a murky brown hue with a tab frothy lacing head. Taste a nice carbonated sweet punch that mellows into a nice grape like finish. This is a very good beer, to savor like you would a fine wine or champagne.

10 bottle.  Light raisin/maple syrup color in the glass with quickly fading head and steady carbonation.  Aroma is spice, candied sugar, raisin, date, honey, and dark sweet malt.  Taste follows the aroma although the raisin/date component gets a bit thick with the heavy alcohol content.  Thick feel in the mouth with the finish a bit too sweet for my personal tastes.  Fairly solid beer for sipping but not up there with the best Belgian strong ales Ive enjoyed.
750 ml bottle, 2010.  Clear dark reddish brown, off-white head.  Dark fruits, candy sugar, plum, and just like the red heavy on the booze.  Not a big fan, that alcohol really gets in the way.
Various bottles from 2000 to 2010, Sweet and dark with little head, 3-4 years old seems to give the optimal flavor before some of the sweetness is lost in an older bottle.

75cl bottle from 2008 shared with friends.
A great beer. I always try and buy a couple a year to put away

2009 bottle. The beer poured a dark brown semi-opaque with a very thin light head.  First impression was the fruity nose. The beer had a great thick mouth feel with lots of fruit up front and caramel on the back end. Quite tasty.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2011 Shared a bottle from 2005 with 2 friends. This really surprised me in a positive way. pours a dark brown with a beige head.  The smell is kinda dark in the nuances with dark fruits, chocolate and some barley kinda feel too it and some hops. Taste is giving you all the dark nuances from the Aroma along with a vinous sour end. Nice!

Smelled tasted like a smooth Quad to me.  Lots of dark fruit, chocolate, resin, and definitely no hops.  Really smooth and sweet, tons of flavor, and no hint that there was even alcohol in it.  Great example of a high end belgian beer.

From notes:

Pours a dark chestnut amber color with a 2.5 finger foamy tan head that has decent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that coats the glass with patches of soapy lacing.

Roasted malt aroma with hints of peppery spice and a prominent dark fruit presence. Hints of plum, raisin, dark cherry and grape balanced by subtle hops licorice, nut and alcohol.

This beer has a wonderful mouthful and is very flavorful. Nice soft carbonation up front with lots of peppery spice that is nicely balanced by a slight medicinal presence, dark fruit and alcohol warmth. Hints of chocolate, caramel, fig, raisin, date and dark cherry all bouncing off of each other. Incredibly complex with the perfect balance of roasty, spicy, sweet and heat. The high ABV is excellently masked however, making this beer dangerously drinkable. Highly recommended!

2008 version, bottle of 750 ml. Cloudy Brown with a thin brown head. Aroma is Caramel, dark fruits, cherry. Medium body with fizzy carbonation. Taste is very sweet, caramel, dark fruits. When is getting warmer, its more bready and yeasty with some alcohol.

Pours a five+ finger pillowy, cream head that fades very slowly leaving a good lace.  Deep cloudy amber/brown color.  Nose is dark fruit and some alcohol.  Good carbonation and medium bodied.  Flavor is sweet dark fruit and hints of alcohol.  $12.99 for a corked and caged 750ml bottle from Beverage Warehouse Winooski, VT. Bottled 2008.

A: Pours a dark brown mahogany with a decent light brown head.

S: Lots of dark fruits, cherries, and some more earthy dried fruits as well. Plenty of yeasty goodness.

T: Much luck the smell with a little bit of extra sweetness thrown in.

M: Fairly full-bodied and creamy. Not too much alcohol taste.

D: Quite drinkable. Split this one with my wife and glad that we had a whole 750 to split.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2009

This is a vintage 2004, and now its October 2010. The color is mahogany-red and the head is creamy. The aroma has notes of raisin, dark fruits, burnt sugar and malt. The flavour is sweet with notes of plum, raisin and other dark fruits, malt og dark candy-sugar/burnt sugar. Its well-balanced, complex and truly nice.

2006 release in 750 ml brown bottle labeled 10%, thankfully donated from a personal collector in Athens, GA USA.
Intnese raisny aroma. Big body matched with full creamy mouthfeel. Deep rich complex malty flavor. Late but powerful alcohol character. All combine very well make a great impression. A superb Grand Cru.

Bottle.  Pours a murky brown with a slight reddish hue.  An initially tall khaki head that fades to a small ring--no lace.  Sweet aroma of prunes, Belgian candi, dates, raisins, and grapes. The flavor is the same.  Very full and very delicious.  Woody, vinous, raisins, dates, dark grapes, a touch a vanilla, and a touch of yeastiness.  Medium to full bodied on the palate with low carbonation.  Very silky, smooth and delicate.  Overall:  this is very far from my favorite style, but this is a complex and delicious brew.  If you are into non-lambic belgians, THIS IS YOUR BREW!!

Truly fit for an emperor. This beer smells like heaven. There is a ton of dark stone fruit with burnt sugar and a touch of bourbon on the nose. Flavor is much of the same with a nice transition from sweet to dry. The flavors meld and then drift away ever so smoothly. The palate could have been a little fuller and certainly left my mouth feeling really wet, but thats not too bad. The appearance was the only average characteristic, lacking much of a head and holding a mediocre dull brown. Overall, extremely delicious, one that I could drink by the liter, and hopefully will.

Draft in a Gouden Carolus glass at Three Floyds.  2007 vintage.  Pours a cloudy amber color with a small khaki head.  Aroma of raisins, alcohol, candi sugar, caramel malts, and apples.  Flavor is boozy, with raisins, figs, sweet caramel malts, grapes, bread, dry yeast.  Medium-bodied, with a malty mouthfeel and moderate carbonation.  Sweet and boozy.

Bottle. Mud brown body with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is raisins, caramel, malt and notes of chocolate. Flavor is raisins, sweet caramel, malt. A little to sweet imo. I couldn´t drink more than 1 small glass.

Bottle.

Dark brown with a small white head. Sweet both in aroma and taste. A lot of dried fruit. Quite heavy on the palate but still pleasantly drinkable. 

It was perfect in front of the fire place.

Sample from [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ beerfest. 2010 version. Dark amberish / red with a thin white head. Aroma is malts, yeast and dark dried fruit. Taste is malts, belgian yeast, fruit, plums, raisins, orange peel, licorice. Mostly on the sweet side, but with some light bitter hobs to, alcohol is well hidden, but adds a nice warming. Very balanced. Full bodied, nice soft carbonation. Great stuff even at this young. 101031

The color was amber/red. The head was thick, creamy, and light beige. The aroma was sweet, belgian yeast, and alcohol. The flavor was sweet at first then brought a dryness. There was also alcohol, and fermented fruit. The palate was smooth. The finish was sweet/dry and warm.

750 cl bottle. 2009 vintage: pours a dark ruby/brownish color with a creamy tanned head. Aroma is toffee, figs, and spices. Some hints of alcohol too. Taste is lightly hoppy with lively carbonation and a creamy texture. Sweet malty flavor and alcohol well hidden. Light dry finish. Gorgeous.

She slid into my glass dressed in deep burgundy marked by mahogany highlights topped with a voluptuous khaki head. Beautiful. Holding her gilded depths up to the light, she is a precious jewel that would be right at home adorning the crown of some noble person. Her head fades into a gentle blanket, and no sooner do I lift her burgundy depths up to my hopefully worthy nose does time stop and beervana descend. Belgium, you have done it again; once more I am your willing disciple of beery humility. Vinous, sour, grapey, plumy, and marked by a wisp of banana cream followed immediately by blueberries and cream atop a generous bowl of homemade vanilla bean ice cream. Her nose exudes creamy berry delights which finish with crisp green apples and pears right off the tree. Rounding the corner, I come right back to more grapes with concord taking center stage while wood and ruby port soften the edges. Are those flower petals I smell? Lilac maybe? I cant take it anymore; smelling is all well and good and she has been very good, but I desire more. Lips meet and goose bumps immediately trace their way from the tippy-top of my head to the tippy-top of my pinkie toe. Vinous, tart, sour, woody, and whoa! Tartness tickles all the way to the back of my throat, grazing the sides of my cheeks along the way. Concord grapes and plums are the first to shine while her creamy mouthfeel revels in banana cream, just a dab please, before her dark berries and ruby port take over. Red licorice streaks on by, and I fall into an ocean of more plums and concord grapes making merry with baby red peaches, pears, apples, cherries with pits, and blackberries. Add some wood to the mix and I am in port heaven while lil Bretty bugs add tart and funk to her berryliciousness. Yes, that is a word because I say so; deal with it. My Cuvee Van de Kaizer Blauw came in a corked 750ml bottle, and with one glass down, I set pen and paper aside and melt into the second half of her liquid nirvana.


Hopefully, I was able to express to a decent extent just how amazing this beer was. I cant wait to see how my 2008 bottle tastes in a few years and seeing as I have a 2009 set aside to age along with one to taste fresh, my cellar is once more looking good.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2016 [10/10] 2009 bottle, 13C. Pours dark brown with a beige coat. Plum, licorice and toffee aroma with fresh figs, orange zest, earthy yeast, cinnamon. Full mouthfeel is only very slightly syrupy, aided by light carbonation. Taste has loads of fruity - as above, perhaps with cherries too - sweetness with some dark sugars. Tidy bitterness leads to finish thats getting towards dry. Some nutty sherry-like notes. Rather elegant. Alcohol is not all that obvious for 11%. Not a brooding beer - its open and full of ripe fruit. The sweetness grew a little too much as it warmed and Im happy I drank it whilst theres some overt bitterness. Better with nuts than cheese FWIW. [3.9][3/13] 2012 bottle. Ivory with a lasting beige coat. Very fruity, earth and leather. Figs, raisins, licorice. Very sweet, alcohol sticks out a bit. Complex and delicious, but a bit lacking in sense of fun.2016 bottle. Freshish. Lets not pretend Im going to try ageing it. Very fruity (fresh figs, prunes, quinces) , only moderately yeasty - really quite clean and not as sweet as recalled. Almost creamy, exuberant dark fruit with some spices and brown sugary dough. Alarmingly drinkable.

Appearance: Ruby colour, thin beige lid.
Aroma: Sweet, dark fruit, jam, sugar, alcohol.
Flavour: Overly sweet, alcohol, sugar, yeast, dried fruit, honey. 
Mouthfeel: Sharp carbonation.
Total: Too sweet for me to reall appreciate it.
UPDATED: OCT 12, 2016 I enjoyed certain aspects of this but it was almost too much. Some what cloying and almost syrupy. The flavors were very good but it came on very strong. Serving: Tap
Bottle. Pours very dark red.. almost brown.Nose is dark fruits and plums with a bit of dough. The taste is slightly smoked plum, raisin and other dark fruits. Very enjoyable solid brew.

2009 750 pours dark hazed mahogany with brighter edges. The aroma at first did not impress me much, but after letting it warm slightly the yeasty esters and spices became more pronounced. There is also a lot of caramel and some dark fruit and a hint of mushroom. The taste is complex with some wood, dark fruit, yeasty spice, lots of sweetness.The alcohol is mild but does show on the finish along with some of that fungal earth. The texture is perfect, very smooth and with rich carbonation. Finish leaves a lot of juicy malt. Very good, but I would have a hard time drinking a whole bottle since it is quite sweet.

Bottle @ home. Deep brown with red glow, small off white head.
Aroma is caramel, lots of malt, spices and liquorice.
Flavour is very sweet of caramel, liquorice and malt. Lot of spices as well.
Very intense but a bit too sweet overall.

Aroma is prunes, figs and raisins. Taste is very sweet, figs again, honey and just molasses. Too sweet. -- After reading ratings Im obviously wrong! Maybe the bottle was stored inproperly at the pub. Rating will be updated when beer is tasted again.

750ml, corked & caged bottle, 2009 edition from grape & gourmet. pours a deep, burgandy brown with a thick, creamy, beige head that leaves nice lacing. aroma is great with loads of sweet cherries, plums, and sweet, belgian yeast with touches of caramel, raisins, and light chocolate with hints of cinnamon and light, grassy hops. flavor is delicious as well big notes of caramel, dark cherries, plum skins, and figs with dark, bready, yeast and light belgian spices with a warming, subtle alcohol presence on the finish. palate is full bodied with very nice carbonation and a nice balance of sweetness, fruit, and spice. overall, a damn nice belgian strong.
2008 bottle at Shakey Fest 10. Cherry, plummy. Sweet fruitiness. Lots of raisin. Some nice alcohol.

2008 750ml bottle. Pours a reddish brown almost a burgundy color with a good well retained head that leaves a bit of lace. The aroma is raisin and brown sugar with some chocolate. The flavor is nicely spicy and mildly roasty with a nice sweetness but it doesnt taste under-attenuated at all. Lots of rich maltiness here.
Bottle: pours a dark reddish brown with a frothy tan head, sweet, candied aroma, taste is sweet and malty, smooth finish

750mL bottle, 2009.  Pours a clear dark red with a fluffy off-white head.  Aromas of dark fruit, bananas, syrup and alcohol.  Dark fruit and port in the flavour with reasonably high sweetness, an alcoholic warmth and mildly acidic.  Medium bodied, average carbonation and quite creamy with a sweet finish.

Bottle.

A - Very dark plum color with some dark ruby hues on the edge. Fairly large, creamy, sticky, toasted marshmallow colored head. Decent retention and a beautiful layer of creamy, sticky lace.

S - Plenty of dark fruit consisting of plum, raisin, and date. Nice sweetness as well with molasses, dark candi sugar, licorice/anise, and a touch of bubblegum. Well spiced with clove, cinnamon, nutmeg, and a touch of coriander. Hints of rum/brandy soaked fruit as well. Some dark malt and a touch of breadiness make the base. Pretty complex aroma.

T  Good mix of dark fruit, spice, and sweet bread flavors throughout the sip. Similar to the nose. Starts with a strong dark, spiced fruit at first. Mid sip has a strong licorice and bubble gum flavor come out. The dark fruit then comes on strong at the end with a bit more of a rum/brandy flavor to it. The sweet bready flavor is a nice persistent undertone throughout the sip.

M - Medium, maybe slightly toward full, body. Has a lush, creamy, persistent kind of feel to it though. Good amount of carbonation.

D - Well balanced and complex beer with a great mix of flavors that had me wanting to drink more. I could see it potentially being a little too sweet/cloying, but I like sweeter beers on occasion and I think it works for the style.

Notes: Vintage 2009. Great beer that is very complex and has a lot of bold, big flavors. Inclusion of licorice and bubblegum flavor is interesting for the style. I really liked the beer, like I said before, some may think it is a bit too sweet, but it makes a great dessert or night caper (although I could see me drinking this other times too!).

Vinous grape and candi aroma. Clear brown,thin yellow head, plenty of carbonation rising from the bottom of the glass. Sweet, yet not cloying, grape and cherry flavor, with some banana undercurrents. Alcohol present, but blends in very well. Modest complexity, but very enjoyable.
Thanks for sharing, bro!  Pours a dark plum color with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is plum, light green grape, with some sugary sweetness.  Taste is much the same - dark fruit, plum.  Pretty good.

Pours a ruby color with medium off-white head.  Aroma is of green apple, plum, light wood, Belgian spice and yeast.  Taste is similar with a bit more green apple bite and dark fruit as well intermixed with the classic clove and light yeast.  Alcohol is well hidden and notes of wood are interwoven with this one.  Solid.

Huge beer. Lovely dark dark amber brown with fluffy head that dies pretty quickly. Nose is raspberry jubes, plums and port. In the mouth it is very full, almost chewy with fruit of the forest, alcohol, cola and port vying for attention with a long finish. This would be massive if aged 4 or 5 years. Still good as it is. 2009 vintage. Well done to slowbeer getting this in at a very decent price!

on tap 5/25/10 at papago...

rusty brown colored body with a short lived pale tan head. 

the aroma and flavor make me cringe... horribly sweet, brown sugar, nail polish, bananas, yeast, spice and a kick of booze. this must be off. i actually returned this... 4/4/4/3/9/2.4
75 cl bottle from 2008. Dark brown/red with very small off-white head. Flavour is malt, dark fruit, well hidden alcohol, prunes, sweet and yeast.
A decent offering, well worth the money and id possibly get it again. Just didnt knock my socks off.

750ml Bottle. 2009 Vintage. Clear, dark brown pour with mahogany highlights and a creamy beige head that doesnt last long but leaves a lot of lace. Aroma is sweet and spicy with notes of caramel, chocolate, dates, cinnamon and raisins plus a hint of aniseed. Flavour is quite similar to the aroma but with added hints of berries and cognac. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with moderate carbonation, some nicely integrated alcohol warmth and a lingering spicy, sweet finish. Great Belgian ale; big, complex and full-bodied, yet very smooth and easy drinking. Reminds me of a very good Christmas ale.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet, 2008 edition. Pours a deep brown body with a reddish hue, only visible against a direct light source. Small off-white retention. Good looking. Smell is dried plumes, booze, candy sugar and raisins. Taste is brown sugar at first, then a fruity hop tone that lingers into figs, raisins and dates. Some alcohol in the undercurrents of the entire flavor. The body is a very full creation, with lingering brown sugar notes and lots of classic Belgian dried fruits as main elements. Comes across as too sugary at first, then the palate dries out to leave hoppy and other fruity elements proper space. Very full-bodied and a nice winter warmer or sipper. This is indeed an ale worthy of a "Kaizer" (Emperor).

Whewww, this beer is a true example of Belgian beer. From the nearly opaque black pour to the thick, off-white head, the beer just looks gorgeous. The smell matches the wonderous appearance with an aroma of dried fruits, burnt sugars, and that indistinguishable nose that is wholly Belgian. From the first sip to the lasting gulp, this brew provides a diverse palate of plums, grapes, brown sugar, and yeast. A well carbonated, medium body hides the 11% body well, with almost no alcohol poking through. What a delightful beer, yummm.

750mL bottle (2009) from Greens in Atlanta courtesy of mitchgt.  Murky mahogany-brown pour with a solid medium head that leaves a 1/2 inch - and light sheets of lacing.  Pleasant aroma of bread, dark fruits, candy sugar and bubble gum.  Taste is sweet and complex:  candy, cinnamon, brown sugar, raisins, butterscotch and belgian yeast.  Its mainly about the dark fruity sweetness - but there are several layers to it.  Excellent brew.

750ml. Gabriels. San Antonio, TX. Pours a murky brown with a nice foamy head in the chimay glass. Head slowly falls. Aroma is sweet, caramel, malty breadiness  , yeast and really smells like sweet bread. The taste is sweet, very brown sugar like, and the yeast comes in and sort of seems like it plays a role in trying to balance out the sweetness. And it does to some degree, while the heat from the alcohol is in the back of the drink. There is some fruitiness involved with apples and a slight nutty flavor and maybe even a dash of chocolate. Now that sound like some good bread with all those ingredients.

Bottle 75cl. A clear dark brown ale with a creamy yellow head. Smell is on dark chocolate, prune and yeast. Aroma is intense on caramel and cassis, very sweet, creamy, a nice vanilla and yeast finish. Small vinous notes with oak flavor, notes of smoked malt too. Nice beer, very drinkable, not acid, not bitter, may be a bit too sweet. A nice experience anyway.

Bottle. Shared amongst several people who all wanted to try this highly rated beers. I dont drink too many Belgian Strong Ales so this is fairly new territory for me. Pours a dark reddish brown mahogany color with a tan head. Smells of sweet dark fruit and raisins. Boozy but smooth. Medium mouthfeel. Almost has "legs" like wine. Good but this would be tough to drink a lot of IMO.
Sweet fruit and malty aroma. Pours dark amber. Smoky notes and definitely sweet with alcohol coming through. Good bitterness, but definitely sweet! Absolutely fantastic!

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2010 2009 vintage...

Pours a very nice murky dark brown with some lovely tan foam that leaves lacing around the glass.

Aroma is good but quite mild compared to the HUGE flavors coming out of this one... massive notes of funky yeast, dark fruits, and alcohol.

Seems well carbonated with just a nice slightly syrupy coating in the mouth. It is a very flavorful beer, and Im glad I tried it but not sure Id seek it out again - the  funky taste and alcohol flavors that come through just dont really float my boat.

Pours dark brown with ruby highlights. Quick diminishing fizzy tan head.  Very fragrant sweet malt aroma.  Taste is sweet malt...Fairly complex notes of caramel, dark cherry, cinnamon bread dough, honey, raisin and some bittering hops on the finish.  Amazing taste although its so sweet that its a bit cloying after a couple glasses.  Hard to say anything bad about it though.  One of the best Ive had.

75cl bottle. 2009 vintage, drunk 2010. 11% abv. Pours dark orange brown. Smells of vanilla, wood and raisins. Tastes sweet, malty. Amazing buttery creamy palate. Sweet finsh with background hop balance. Mmm mmm mmm mmm.

2008 Vintage. Bottle, thanks to Keith, who is awesome.  He was pretty apologetic for trading me something I could buy locally. Little does he know that I am an incredibly cheap bastard who likely would never have bought this for myself. I still plan on guilting him for it at a later date though... (heh heh heh) unless hes reading this, in which case, Keith, you can just forget about that last part...Pours medium to dark brown, paler than cola, medium, crazy-persistent, off-white head, fantastic lacing. Okay, were off to a good start. Nose is candy, stale hops, really cool sweet/spicy yeast note, plus a cardamom/coriander spice note separate from the yeast, a bit of sarsaparilla/rootbeer, very candylike, which seems to be a Gouden Carolus thing. Carbonation is spot-on where I like it for this style, and the alcohol is staggeringly well hidden. I wouldnt guess this at 11%. Flavors dont quite live up to the promise of the nose, jujubes, tart cola, red fruits, mild spiciness. Lovely nose, mouthfeel, and appearance, but lets you down on flavour. Perhaps more bottle age? I may have to break down and buy a couple for cellaring...

2009 Bottle. Dark red-brown color with a big off-white head, not lasting. Aroma is sweet, caramel, sugary almost, with dried fruit, or cherries. Taste is very sweet with, again, some fruit. Strong alcohol feel, but not as full bodied as Id expect. Massive brew, but a bit too sweet for my taste. I would be interested in an barrel aged version of this.

Pours a dark brown, aromas of cramel and vanilla almost like a cognac or S.A. Utopias, taste is a wonderful full bodied beer like between a stout and a quad. Warm notes of Carmel and vanilla, absolutely fantastic beer.
Dark amber color with a short lasting head. Smells of fruit and caramel. It has a nice fruity taste with a hint of cinnamon and a slight tang to it.

Aroma of rich molasses and plums and raisin fruits.  Pours deep dark amber, very long lasting lacing on the glass. Very smooth, high sweetness with an apparent low bitterness (but might actually be higher) Lots of fruityness on the tongue, full bodied without a doubt, low carb, sweet long finish. Quite an amazing beverage, rivals the best out there.

750ml bottle from Northgate.  Dark brown/amber pour with a one finger, crater filled tan head.  Sweet caramel and fruity aromas.  Flavor is more caramel and fruit with apple being more prominent.  Finish is smooth and subtle with more apple notes.  As the beer warms up, the apple flavors give way to a raisin type of flavor.  Exceptional beer from start to finish.
Bottle from Cavie at cwsamples bachelor party.  Dark reddish brown pour with a nice head.  Aroma is dark fruit, cinnamon, yeast, and alcohol.  Taste is mostly the same with a stronger alcohol kick.

A- Body is a dark brown, nearly black that pours with a 1/2 finger head and leaves traces of light lacing in the glass.

S- Biscuity raw dough, strong alcohol, toffee, licorice, anise, raisin, a hint of butter.

T- Lots of licorice and anise upfront with an offensive buttery biscuit backbone. There is a good amount of spicy belgian yeast underneath. Finish is quite medicinal with a bite of alcohol.

P- Moderate carbonation with a medium to heavy weight full body that has a slightly doughy consistency.

O- Im really hoping that this was a bad bottle. The buttered biscuit is quite overwhelming and masks the more complex components of the brew. I am willing to give this another try-but couldnt finish it this time- luckily this was shared amongst a few of us do it didnt go to waste. Side note- I dont like their tripel either...

Serving type: bottle

Bottle with big thanks to fata2683.  Opened in honor of cwsamples bachelor party.  Pours a foggy reddish orange color.  Head dissipates quickly.  Very yeasty nose with full fruit elements.  Taste is spicy and sweet right off the bat with a solid alcoholic tingle on the palate.  Finish provides some sweet grain elements.  Very nice.
Very controlled sweetness in the taste. Molasses, vanilla, mild winter spicing (cinnamon, nutmeg), some fruit.

Dark, red-brown body with heavy lacing and a white head. Lactose, diacetyl, nut, and yeast in the nose. Nut, brown sugar, and biting yeast rule the flavor, some metallic elements emerging through the finish where some medicinal cherry shows up. Thick, creamy body that clashes with the dry flavor profile and buttery aroma. This is contrasting and unpleasant, tough to drink, and marred in each aspect. My first drain-pour in quite some time, though I had already drank more than enough for the evening.

A-pours dark ruby red with a hint of haze, light tan creamy head and good lace left behind.

S-the nose brings lots of bready malts, notes of diacetyl, toffee and caramel behind, a good bit of anise, rum soaked cherries in the back.

T-follows the nose, bready malts, diacetyl, toffee and caramel, anise, rum soaked cherries in the back.

M-smooth and creamy on the palate, chewy and full body, good carbonation and nice crisp finish.

D-seems to be a bit of a mess and shows a good bit of alcohol in the back.  also has a fair amount of diacetyl.  must need age or something imo.

2009 Vintage. Pours a clear mahogany with thin beige head which settles quickly. Aromas of dark fruits, cherry-brandy, nuts and caramel. Soft mouthfeel, medium bodied, Again, dark fruits and warming alcohol and dry bitter hop notes on the background. X-tra point on the palate for the lovely long finish.

750 ml bottle 2009 a dark brown colored beer with a beige head aroma malts caramel spices dry and dark fruits liqueur and alcohol taste caramel dry and dark fruits spices liqueur and alcohol hints a very nice beer

Pours ruby and cloudy with white head that laces well.  Aroma is heavy malt, with notes of bread, caramel, grain, toffee, and dark fruit.  Taste is similar to aroma with more tastes of raisin, prunes, dates, toffee, and tobacco, with a dry finish thats also a bit boozy.

Bottle(0,75l) 2008-version shared with boyfriend spkevin. Glad we shared, couldnt have drank the full bottle by my self. Pours a dark ruby beer with a tan head. Nose is of yeast, raisins, grapes and a little alcohol. Taste is sweet, caramel, syrup, liquorice. Full bodied and sticky.

2008 bottle from Berts Bierhuis. A good looking beer. Pours a dark ruby red/ brownish beer with a decent white/tan head. Very strong aroma which I really liked. Hints of dark fruits, alcohol, brown sugar and raisins. Taste is the same with a dry, long finish. Full bodied beer. Quite sticky but overall very enjoyable.

Bottles shared by Boutip, Merci!!!

All 750 ml bottles.

2009 Dark brown with red highlights, thick foamy mocha head with very good retention and beautiful lacing. Aroma is alcohol, spices, barley sugar candy, brandy, cherry and yeast. Flavor is. Barley sugar candy, alcohol, cognac, candied fruits, vanilla, figs, malt, candies and dates. Full body with a liquorous mouthfeel.

2008. Aroma is plums, rhum, sugar, malt, butter, caramel, figs, medicinal herbs. Flavor is Caramel, butter, malt, wood, vanilla and alcohol. (a bit less alcohol then the 2009). Body is a tiny bit thinner.

2007. Aroma is candies, a lot of alcohol, brandy, caramel, toffee, butter, herbs, spices, custard and calvados. A bit of tartness in the nose. Flavor is candied fruits, dates, caramel, a lot of alcohol, plums, herbs, a lot of sweetness and some herbs in the final. 

2006. Aroma is salty with caramel, butter, yeast, a bit less alcohol, fruit cake. Flavor is not as salty as expected with less alcohol and herbs than the 2007.

2005. Similar as 2006 with a bit more alcool and fruits. Mouthfeel is more aqueous.

2004. Aroma is plums, dates, alcohol, dried fruits, raisins and brown sugar. Flavor is caramel, dark fruits, caramel, sugar and custard. 

I am amazed at how well this beer aged, the 2004 has still a lot of potential. A truly splendid beer.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2012 2011 edition: aroma: whisky single malt, avelã, fuge, alcohol, malte moderado, toffee, trufa, milk chocolate, macadamia. ap: small frothy light browh head. dark brown flat thick body. mostly diminishing. fair lacing. if: heavy sweet light bitter. ff: very strong sweet light bitter. frutas secas dominam o paladar. dulçor escalante, permeado por dulçor alcoolico, poderia ser bem menor. Mais agradável que a versão 2009 anteriormente resenhada. retrogosto também doce demais. sabor bem maltado. 100s

5/8/10:small frothy offwhite head. virtually none lacing. fully diminishing. murky thick amberish-brown body. aroma: heavy malt, chocolate, mild coffee, brown sugar and alcohol. if: moderate sweeet and light bitter. ff: moderate sweet and bitter; average duration. palate: full body, syrupy texture, medium carbonation and metallic and moderate alcoholic finish. sabor complexo, delicioso dulçor de chocolate e frutas secas. disfarça o alcool com maestria, gosto suave de alcool que permanece até o retrogosto sem ser agressivo. apesar do nome e do capricho evidente com que foi produzida, faltam nuances mais complexas. sabor caramelizado. tecnicamente perfeita, mas me decepcionou por nao oferecer um diferencial que me surpreendesse. 130s

UPDATED: APR 17, 2012 75 cl bottle year 2008, pours deep dark with a short creamy head, aroma of dark fruit, malt and yeast with a note of alcohol as well, taste follows the nose, long lingering finish, very nice.

Thanks for Armando629 for sharing. Poured deep amber color with an off-white, respectable lacing head. Rich aroma that included plums, molasses, dark fruits, and alcohol. Sweet taste in a dense body with medium carbonation. A complex, strong beer with a dry finish. Alcohol is there, but blends well with the beers sweetness. Overall a very nice beer.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2010 Bottle at home. Darker then i suspected, some redish inside. Good head, holds good. Looks good in the glass. Good fine taste, maybe a bit to much prunes/fruity, but a really fine beer. Edit: Tryed a 10 years old bottle at 13 nov 10, thanks to a friend. Still decent for sure,fruity, the caramel seems to comes trough on an other way, low carbonation.

Today Ive opened a 2009 bottle.
Poured in a Tulip for vintage wine it looked Dark brown color with minimal head. 

Very complex aroma. You can smell caramel, chocolate, banana, licorice, raisin, vanilla. The aroma seems to change continuosly

Sweetness slightly prevale on the bitterness but its well balanced. You can also feel a spicy flavour in the background.

Very nice full thick (not too much) body 
 
Excellent served with the slowly roasted piglets leg, cooked in apple juice and served with roasted apples (lightly frosted with honey).

Simply fabulous coupled with dark bitter chocolate (70% and a cru 100% cocoa) and an home made shortbread apple pie

Recommended +++

2008 version, 11%. Very raisiny, thick like a concentrate. Too concentrate. Very nice balance, playing on all taste dimensions.

 Purchased in Kihoskh.
Overwhelming aromas of sweest fruits and raisins. Slightly too sweet but could be better when drinked at the right time.
great beer after a meal. very fruity, with a deep finish. dark fruits instantly hit your tongue when you take a drink. would never know this was 11% by its taste. but watch out....

Draft at the Fly Rod Tap Room in Waterbury, VT - Poured a dark reddish brown in color with a small light tan head that faded to nothing.  Aroma is malty and sweet with *lots* of dark fruit.  Flavor is also quite sweet and the dark and very complex fruitiness is amazing.  Little evidence of the ABV.  Finish is fruity, sweet and lingering.  This was VERY enjoyable!

This was a 2004 vintage bottle. Poured a dark color with a half finger of head that had very good retention. Smell certainly had that belgian candy sugar with a good bit of dark fruit. Taste had a strong sense of apple, pear and raisins. Candy sugar is also quite prevalent but it is tempered by the fruit sweetness. This has aged remarkably, with a very nice balanced feel. Very well worth aging for six years.
caramel, banana, earthy, brown, clear, tan foam, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation,
I does reminds me of trapist in its flavors of port, raisins and sweetness. But the sweetness is a touch too high making it too easy to drink and the palate is not thick enough.

Appearance is ruby red with white head. Aroma of fermented fruits, yeast, port wine, prunes and raisins. Taste is very sweet with hints of fruit and alcohol. Overall this beer is very interesting, a bit to sweet and heavy for me but it would probably get a lot better after some aging.

Bottle aged 10 years.  Aroma is strong with alcohol, dark fruits, sweet malts.  Notes of cinnamon and other spices stand out.  On the palate, it is slightly under carbonated (I assume from the aging).  The flavor really brings out the cinnamon.  I would like to try this fresh to compare.

2009 bottle.  Very dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is sweet and suggests caramel and candy.  Flavor is very sweet, tasting of caramel, toffee, and vanilla with little noticeable alcohol, along with a certain earthiness that helps keep this from one-dimensional sweetness.  Good, flavorful, but maybe not quite Emperor worthy.
Bottle 750 ml vintage 2009. Dark brown color with white not lasting head. Aroma cherry. fruits, sweet bread.Taste very sweet caramel, cherry, sugar. Full boby, soft feeling.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2012 Smells sweet and cherry-ish.  Deep amber with a strong head.  Syrupy cherry and candy sugar flavor...a bit too much.

Additional 2000 bottle (~10 yrs old)  Almost no aroma...maybe slightly musty-dirty, caramel.  Deep brown in color with no head.  Super-subdued mustiness; hints at dry fruit flavors, though a bit watery.

2009 vintage. Thanks to my buddy for this one. Dark brown pour with ruby highlights in the body. Minimal to no head. Sweet acidic smell, dried fruits, raisins, plums, and a little dough. Taste is dark friuts, figs, and a bit of yeast. Thick and syrupy. A bit too sweet for my liking. Didnt realize the 11% until the next morning.
V.2006. Dark brown with persistent white head. Clove, banana, pineapple, caramel, brown sugar, fantastic, a cross between a quad and a weizen bock. Full bodied and a lush finish. Awesome beer.

Smells of caramel and sweetness.  Has a nice appearance dark with a tan head.  This is the sweetest beer I have ever drank.  Not bitter at all.  Im not sure that is a good thing although this brew is very drinkable.  It is full bodied with an average carbonation.  Overall, I thought I was gonna like this because of the sweetness.  I now see that too much is too much.  This is tasty and if you ever wanted to catch a buzz from a class of soda then try this beer.

Appearance: 3/5
Dark hazy amber liquid with a small dirty white foam.

Smell: 8/10
Dried fruit, raisin, plums.

Taste: 8/10
Dried fruit, yeast, plums and wine.

Mouthfeel: 4/5
Medium smooth and medium carbonation. Puckering mouthfeel.

Comment:
A fruity and nice belgian ale. Lots of flavour and none of them bad. Despite the high alcohol this was fairly easy to drink and it didnt feel very boozy. This beer is probably best on its own but probably works great with some cheeses.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2011 75cl bottle vintage 2001. Dark red to brown color with some tiny sediment and a beautiful beige head that leaves some nice lacing even after 9 years in the bottle! Aroma is full of fruit with especially apples and a nice touch of porto with some alcohol. Beatifull aged aroma! Taste is sweet with a nice apple and porto taste. The aftertaste is sweet with again some nice apples. The body is full, mouthfeel is soft and the drinkabilty is superb! Ive also tasted the 2007 version and this is more malty in aroma and taste and has a nice light bitter taste. The aged porto taste is not present in the 2007 version. Both old and young versions are superb and this is a magnificent aging beer. A true Champion!

750ml bottle from IPB
Appearance : Coca cola colored with tiny head. Short retention. Some lacing

Aroma : Sweet fruity belgian yeast with some alcohol.

Taste : Very sweet and fruity. Yeasty. A bit nutty. Brown sugars. Some alcohol

Finish : Warm and nutty

Overall : Very sweet and rich. Thin but lively carbonation. Truly a classic.

Ok yeah this beer pretty much kicks ass.  So thanks to BierBauch for this one.  There are alot of qualities of this beer that are reminiscent of St. Bernardus Abt12 but also a ton of uniqueness in here as well.  Aroma is similar to Bernardus with the heavy hit of yeast and bread dough but also sweeter as it has a more robust dark fruit characteristic.  The aroma filled the room as soon as I started to pour it.    Flavor is unique while at the same time keeping some of the great qualities of other favorite Belgians.  Theres definitely more chocolate in the mix, along with large supply of dark fruits such as plums and figs.  There are some hops as well that add a nice balanced bitterness.  The palate is twice as heavy as I was expecting.  Quite thick and syrupy but still remains soft and just plain fun to drink.  A real treat.  Im going to acquire some more of these to throw in the cellar.

Bottle, pours dark brown with thin tan head.  Aroma is sweet with dark fruits, caramel and malts.  Great appearance and aroma.  Big flavor of dark fruits, caramel, chocolate, coffee, and dark malts.  Really impressive beer with full body and warm finish.

2008 Bottle, Village De La Biere, Strasbourg, France.  Been keenly anticipating breaking this fella open for a little while now. Poured a dark reddy tinged brown with a fading tan head. Aroma was syrupy sweet and honey laden, with caramel malt, spice and booze lingering with intent also. Complex sweet and rich flavour that retained the elements in the nose and more.  A plethora of spices in there, orange peel, brown sugar, yeast,  earthy malts, leading to a wee bit of alco burn in the finish.  Im curious as to what shape the assistance of the public in brewing this takes.  Bet theres a few interesting secret ingredients lurking in here. Quality lies herein.

Bottle at home. Pours a clear dark ruby red color with a creamy, off-white head leaving some lacing. Very subtle yet complex aroma of red fruits, brown sugar, some wine hints and many spices. Flavor is fruity again, some alcohol present, slightly sour yet very well balanced. Really drinkable and very tasty.

2004 bottle sampled at the SLC tasting 1/23/10 
Appearance: Poured a dark brown with a nice tan head 
Aroma: Belgian yeast, candy, fruits sweet malts 
Taste: Sweet malts, Belgian candy, dark fruit 
A very good Belgian Strong Ale. Very smooth and crisp, well balanced.

2008 bottle.  The pour was turbid brown with a short, creamy tan head.  The aroma was tons of malt and spice over dark fruit.  The flavor was loaded with cinnamon and clove, with plenty of malts and a touch of citrus.  The mouthfeel was medium to full in body and the alcohol was well hidden.  Good, just a little overly spiced for my taste.

750 mL bottle pours a deep tobacco brown with minimal, quickly dispersing off white head into a chalice; nice lacing.  Aroma of raisin, plumb, green apple, brown sugar, well malted with a hidden woody aspect.  Plumbs give way to tart green apples which dominate the flavor profile.  Brown sugar/molasses with plenty of malt.  Very well balanced with only a slight booziness in the finish.  Fluffy mouthfeel with low carbonation; full bodied.  Gets sweeter as it warms.  Very nice brew.
06 vintage. aroma is caramel malts and sweetness. drinks with caramel malts, sweet like maple syrup, roasty. thin body and finishes clean.
UPDATED: DEC 27, 2016 dark brown coloured body with a off white head a spicy malty fruity aroma a spicy malty fruity caramel sweet taste with a alcholic spicy bitter finish

Flaske: Årgang 2004: Fantastisk portvinsduft på en mørkebrun uklar øl med en flot karbonering. Smagen er portvin men stadig hvinende sød efter 5 år på flaske. Mundfylden er sirup, men overraskende uden nogen alkohol. Flot flot øl, men dog en tand for sød til helt at kunne udfylde potentialet fra duften.

Brown coloured beer with small off-white head and medium carbonation. Malty caramelish aroma. Full bit creamy and sparkling palate. Finish is roasted ending bitter. Cant find myself in the high average rating, its ok but I liked the less rated red one more.

2009 labeled, corked, 75 cl Bottle. Pours Dark mahogany with ruby highlight. Tiny fingerwide tanned head shows quite cohesive lacing with confident retention. Moderate fruity esters on the nose - a bit similar to GC classic. Not so dried fruity, a bit woody with plums, and dark grapes and then a some dark roasted, but sweetish chocolate and rum like (phenolic?), spicy interplay. The first sip leaves a very sweet, dark cherry kind of yeasty, malty fullness on the tounge. Definitely a sipper, but only a very subtle alcohol warmth is sensible. Big bombs of dark cherry and raisin-like esters, caramelized sugars, interesting peppery, yeasty notes smoothly surfacing in your palate and seating there for a long, holy time. :) Some chewy, crisp, but peppery belgian hops are maybe present but not dry or bitter at all. It would be interesting to try an older vintage how would improve the fruity character, and howd mellow the alcohol. Very solid beer, still at this fresh vintage. Amazingly tasteful, chewy, thick and rich dark belgian ale without being too distinguish or unique. Really my kind of beer.

750ml bottle, 2009.  Pours very dark copper/brown with a one finger light beige head.  Very nice, complex beer that evolves and changes.  Aromas range from very fruity, dark fruits, cherries, light apple, some yeast.  Flavors are predominantly fruity, cherries, dark fruits, sometimes some chocolate really comes through, some pear, yeasty, bready belgian goodness.  Alcohol is quite present.  Only real knock I have, but I think it will get better with age.  Mouthfeel is rich, but with high carbonation for the style.  Very rich and delicious beer overall.  Glad to finally try this one.
2007 version. Full malt richness, with caramel and dark fruits--a step richer than the Classic. Lots of cherry. Silky smooth--perfect body. Rich and well-balanced. Superb.

2008 Bottle, dark, almost black, normal beige head. Malts, yeast and candy in the nose. Taste is malty, dark, herbal, a bit sweet, hoppy and and a nice, average finish. 
The second glass reveals a thick, almost syrupy creamy taste, but also a smell of pee. Nevertheless a good beer, but not above the classic Gouden Carolus imo.

Bottle from Vanuxeem beer warehouse near Ypres. Deep brown pour with nice tan head. Aroma of port and dark fruits. Sweet, complex, dark fruit, spice, warming. A contemplative Belgian strong ale from one of the best breweries on earth.

Large biege head good carbonation colour is plum like or dark wine aroma banana candy dark fruit vanilla maltiness flavour clove banana candy raisin plum cinnamon brown sugar creamy smoothness typical of a gouden carolus has a fizz on the palate yeasty goodness through the beer sweet but not rich not much bitter not that it matters finish great mix of flavours smooth a fizz on the palate morishing stuff.

This beer pours a dark brown almost black with a thin tan head that dissipates quickly.  The aromas are light citrus and dough.  The flavor is sweet and yeasty and not too dry.  This was a pleasure to drink.  Cheers!

2008 bottle.  Crap, I thought this was a quad.  Dark reddish brown pour with off white, whispy head.  Brown sugar, raisin, belgian yeast, candi sugar.  Flavor is pruney, grapey, caramel, some dates.  A bit of Belgian yeast and maybe a touch of spice. A bit vinous.  Syrupy mouthfeel with some nice carbonation.  Finishes sweet.  Pretty decent belgian,

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2014 Bottle at en Öl och Whiskeymässa 2014, 2014-04-11 Göteborg vintage 2004
AR: rasins, chocolate, toffee
AP: dark coppery, frothy beige head
F: heavy warming, belgian yeasty, rasins toffee, white wine, grainy
New rating 3,8 - new average (4,0+3,8)/2=3,9

, 2009-12-12, Göteborg

AR: green grapes, honey, coffey
AP: Coca cola colures body, steady 1 cm thickof white head
F: Belgian yeast, butter schotch, red currant, spirit,
Additional comment: very nice distinctive curtains

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2010 (2006, 2009, 2010, and also a 2007 aged 4 years)

§lct-br, thick creamy head, full body, ^co2.

fruity malty §iron ^alchl aroma.

malty iron-hop T1, caramel dark-fruit T2, alchl §burnt T3.

smooth, fruity,  very-low-bitterness, ^flavorful, ^drinkable.
maybe slightly less complex than the abbeys when fresh, but absolutely wonderful with a few years aging, as everything melds together and the malt and hops drop back, allowing more of the caramel sweetness and the bubble gum and banana yeast esters to emerge.

2009 batch, 750 ml bottle, 11/27/09.  Pours dark brown with ruby highlights, with light tan head.  Not a lot of head retention.  Odor is plums, almost grape juice.  Slight (but not offensive) green apple aroma.  Hits the mouth sweet and grapey.  Definitely some belgian candy syrup flavor.  Plenty carbonated, but not to the extreme like some of this style.  Mouthfeel is very smooth  one of the best, most surprising features of this beer, actually.   No metallic flavor, alcohol is very well hidden, no astringency.  Overall, Id say this beer is essentially flawless, though a little one-dimensional with the dark fruity sweetness.   Reminds me a lot of a Bernardus Abt 12, although not as dry.  This beer was young.  It is going to age very well.

2008 bottle.  A huge tan head causes significant delay in enjoying this beer.  Pour is a very cloudy dark brown that is almost porter a color.  A complex aroma of spice, dark fruit, vinous notes, and cherry wood.  Flavor is delicious.  Complex fruit with both dark and tropical, alcohol, spices, sweetness and more sweetness.  This was a very tasty beer for a beer drinker with a sweet tooth (like myself).  However, it would have been a great beer to share.  By the end of the 750 the sweet flavor had grown stale.

The first thing I noticed about the 2007 version of this beer is the alcohol notes on the aroma.  It wasnt offensive, but definitely present.  The beer pours a dark amber/brown that shines red in the glass without much head.  With the alcohol, the beer has a fresh sweet caramel nose with a slight date smell.  The taste mirrors the aroma and as the beer warms up, more alcohol notes are noticeable in the taste.  Good beer.

And, if I were to have the pleasure of drinking this beer again, I would drink it cold!

Dark chesnut colour with fine beige foam on top. Rich nose with hints of brown sugar, dried fruits, caramel, plumpudding and spices. Taste is complex, full with nice roundings and smooth elements like candi, dried plums, nutmeg and soft hops. Alcohol well hidden.

2009 750mL -> trappist glass.  Pours a dark reddish brown with tan head.  Head laces slightly.  The nose is quite dynamic: molasses and gingerbread followed by orange peel and eventually pecan - top notch.  The tasting is quite pleasant milk chocolate and maple syrup - not as complex to the tongue as the nose would suggest.  This ale is very sweet and has only a hint of bitter at the finish.  The mouthfeel is creamy and syrupy.  Overall, this is an excellent belgian brown, though sweeter than I prefer.  Cellaring is definitely in order.  If only I could get this product unrefrigerated.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2010 Aroma was sweet.  Smelled of candy and fruit -- great.  The taste of the beer was exceptional and I barely tasted the 11%.  Syrupy, fruity, smooth.  A bit too sweet.

Re-rating on the 2010.  Much, much more sweet.  Way too sweet in fact.

Bomber into glass: dark ruby pour with only slight ring of very light tan head.   I guess I didnt expect it to be so sweet but it was beautifully done -- not too sweet.  Good malts, a little yeast and caramelized banana flavor.
Bottles. Dark redish brown in colour. Nose of caramell and banana. Tasted of banana and vanilla. A bir sweet. A new favourite...
Deep brown appearence. Aroma of banana and dirt, rich and deep impact. Tastes of red wine and with a distinct fiery tone.

Vintage 2000 Edition, thnx Skortila!:Black, brown colored brew. Malty, port-like aroma, not heavy. Flavor is malty, sugary sweet, raisin and a port-like aftertaste. Flavor becomes more and more smooth after warming up. At first its a bit thin, then its more smooth. Watch out for the left-overs in the bottle. Overall very enjoyable, but not really that special.

Bottle. 2009 vintage.

The pour is dark reddish brown with a big off-white head that leaves nice lacings.

The smell is big an spot on. Lots of malty aromas of caramel, brown sugar and toffee. Pleasant heavy fruit aromas, yeast and alcohol. 

The flavor is really sweet. From start to finish this one is all about sweetness - toasty malts, caramel, brown sugar, toffee. Notes of vinous fruits, wood, yeast and grass. The finish has some bitterness to it, more sweetness and notes of alcohol, hops and spices.

It has a full body and quite a lot of carbonation, which is welcome here since it lightens the heavy character, if only just a bit.

All in all, a complex, balanced and tasty beer. Due to the sweetness, it gets quite demanding after a while.

~Strong sweet alcohol scent with dried cherries, lots of darker sugars, some spices.
~Pours a dark deep amber brown color with small persistant creamy head.
~Sweet raisin and plum flavor, with brown sugar. Very sweet.
~Very thick creamy feel. Full bodied, chewy. 
~ Wow! intense brew. Super malty and thick. I normally dont like beers like this. This one is a nice exception.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 750 ML 2008. Despite a very lovely smell nothing in this beer works for me. Its a complete taste overload of sweetness upon sweetness, and ends up coming across somewhat close to an ice tea.

Dark red brown appearance with a thick taned head.  Aroma: toffee, caramel, cherries, vanilla, eggnog and brown sugar.  Flavor:  alcohol, cherries, salt, cinnimon and brown sugar.  Palate: full body, lively carbonation, oily with adry finish.

750mL Bottle.Lovely beer. Overall a bit sweet, but great complexity. Pours an red-amber colour wth good amount of dense tan head. Aroma of spice, port, and apples. Body is thick, and alcohol well hidden by the sweetness. Notes of caramel sweetnes, plums, nutmeg, nuts, and fruit notes. Finish iis slight bitterness, but very clean.

2008 Vintage. Pours a cola brown with beige head. The head sticks around for a while. Aroma is woody, nutty and malty. Notes of licorice. Flavor is sweet - very sweet. Notes of dark fruits, bananas, raisins, figs. Finishes on that sweet note.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. (2008) Split this with Jefferson in the top of the ninth inning as the Phillies clinched the National League Championship for the second consecuitve year. Pours a vivid, electric amber with a velvety, creamy tan head. Aroma of apples, grapes, raisins, vanilla, honey, clove, and hints of pepper, nutmeg, and ginger. Fuller bodied with a lovely warming sensation. Hides the alcohol perfectly. Bold, crisp, tart finish. Excellent Belgian strong ale. Highly recommended.

This beer rocks.  The aroma is complete with malts, licorice, and candi additives.  What really surprised me was how well the licorice flavor was present, but did not take over.  The beer is very complex.  You taste a rosted malt flavor, the spice, the licorice, some fruits, and you get the bittering hops at the end.  The alcohol content is fantastic.  The only way you can tell it is strong is if you evaporate the beer off of you tounge by strongly breathing in.

750ml bottle (2008) poured into a tulip glass produced a medium-thick tan head with brown body.  Flavor and aroma of sweet, dark fruits and sugars with hints of caramel/molasses.  The 11% alcohol was well concealed.  Add this to my favorites list.

Oh my. Where to start? From the bottle, dark brown with a small head. Aroma is wonderful. Ripe fruit, very wine like, brown sugar, vanilla. Flavor is sweet fruit , vanilla and candied sugar up front with a slightly bitter end. Finishes with a nice burn. Im drinking this while watching a football game and a Coors Lite commercial comes on.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 De couleur brune foncée, elle a une belle mousse beige qui colle très bien au verre. Elle dégage des arômes de caramel, de malt chocolaté et dalcool. Très bien balancée, la Van De Keizer bleu est veloutée en bouche et nous offre de déliceuses saveurs de caramel, de malt, dalcool et de chocolat et ce, tout en douceur. Très bonne bière complexe.

Bottle shared by anand, thanks playa!  Pours a mahogany brown with a beige head.  apple crisp, brown sugar, caramel, plums, dates, tangerines, nutty, honey raison, candied sugar, medicine.  Nice!  tangy dark fruit.  great beer.  Booze is well hidden to say the least.  Really tasty beer.

Bottle from Kegs & Barrels in Plano, TX. Pours a dark cloudy brown with a strong fizzy beige head. Aroma is great! Nice dark fruit, citrus and malt, some farm house as well.Flavor is semi sweet, farm house, dark fruit, malt, light dark roast, light tartness/citrus. Mouth feel is medium body with fizzy carbonation. Overall, a very tasty beer! Would want again.
