text: 750 ml bottle, 2002 vintage.  Smallish off-white head topping a very dark brown/red ruddy body; a bit less muddy than the Carolus d'Or I had last night.  Sensational rich candyish nose:  chocolate cherries, caramel/toffee and a hint of smoke, and a light vanilla-whiskey tone underlying it all.  Tasting, you realize a more complex, intricate flavor sensation than in the "classic" version, just as compelling in its sweetness, its thick, smooth but never cloying body, its light alcohol presence.  Cherries again, and raisins, and vanilla, and caramel... its hard for me to come up with greater superlatives than I did on the "regular" rendition...this really is close to flawless.  Perhaps the alcohol is a little prominent near the end, but it is hard for me to think of anything I'd want different in the nose or flavor; this has few peers.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2005 The Dor has always been a favorite and this one held up to that and some more. Matta has really said it all - wonderful and a big thank you to him for sharing. And many thanks to the Keizer for sharing as well.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2008 Vintage 2002
 The body was a murky tawny golden brown. The aroma was amassed with supple but forward notes of caramel malts, and both dark and light fruity suggestions, plums, apples, pears, dates, raisins and a lovely presentation of banana. The flavor was remarkably blissful, with long distinct notes of brown sugar, leading to toffee and caramel, then a freshly baked brick of dense banana nut bread yeasty, sweet and sticky euphoric! 
<br The palate was as yielding and velvety as a French Bordello, finish was syrupy with fruity esters. I couldnt ask for more out of a beer!  
 This beer may rate out as one of the best beers I have ever sampled! It was complex and utterly extraordinary!

Thin head which does not last long.  Decent carbonation keeps it regenerating nicely though.  Wow, awesome aroma.  Rich and meaty with grapes, raisins, plums, caramel and a nose that lets you know that the alcohol is present.  Color is a dark cloudy red/brown.  Flavor is a little thick and sweet and potent.  Big alcohol kick and warming.  Complex, malty flavor with roasted grains, caramel and molasses.  Finish is sweet and leaves a film in the mouth.  A very good belgian that I would love to try again.

750ml 2003 bottle.  Pours a very deep dark amber with a nice froth that is constantly replenished.  This beer has a very sweet and malty aroma, it's not really strong, but it's pleasant.  Taste is sweet, plum, heavy malts, spice, caramel.  The mouth feel is soft and mellow, probably from the plentiful carbonation.  This is a really balanced but complex brew.  Very good!  I'd like to get more to age longer than a year.

Dark brown color. Medium head. Aroma is malty, fruity and sweet. Medium bodied. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are slightly spicy. The malts really shine through in this beer. Very smooth and velvety taste. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.Dark brown color. Medium head. Aroma is malty, fruity and sweet. Medium bodied. Malts are fruity and sweet. Hops are slightly spicy. The malts really shine through in this beer. Very smooth and velvety taste. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

I enjoyed a 2003 Grand Cru of The Emperor in March 2004. Dark copper color. Crisp carmel, fruity aroma. Smooth, sweet, carmel spiciness. Very full,  thick palate. Very well hidden alcohol content. Good beer, the Belgians rarely dissappoint me.

A sweet, malty, heavy nose with hints of candy. The first thought I had was this beer would be GREAT with age. A big mouthfeel that was like eating a chocolate, banana, port-filled cake. Very thick and malty.  I've stashed a few of these away.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2004  Chimay chalice, close to room temp From a ruby brown body mounted with a fully diminishing big light brown head emanes a powerful sweet aroma. Ultra-sweet in fact, full of red licorice flavours, almost too much for its own good, but decadent nevertheless. Quite spicy as well as you'd expect from a belgian grand cru (herbal thyme and sage), lots of fruits (orange, lemon peel). Just a big malty nose altogether with restrained dusty yeastiness. As it warms, it acquires a powdery chocolate feel as well. In mouth, it's still very sweet, with more alcohol than I expected, vinous candi sugar. Lots of malty flavours to decorticate: mint, grapes, orange with floral qualities... Aftertaste is long and made me think of a banana split with touches of alcohol and licorice. A complex beer, definitely a sipper with this big medium-thick body and a low carbonation level. A dessert by itself.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2004 (2003 bottle drank in March 04) : Splendid marzipan and bourbon fission in fuming candi sugar emissions...A marvelous sweet jet stream engulfing dark fruit cream (prunes, dates, cherries) in its immortal vitality...A glorious licorice cigar enlightening meritorious clovey grapes...Picturesque rum heat and victorious chocolate maple syrup...A mighty sipper with a depth in malt sweetness to appease, at once, a most severe case of sweet tooth and a complexity-seeking beer geek... 

(8%abv, 2000 bottle): BEWARE!!!! Apart from being lighter in alcohol, this vintage is not up to the high standards of decadence of the most recent vintages!!! Earthy yeast and toffee notes brawl with the alcohol in a disorderly fashion and ultimately become a meager shadow of what the 2003 always offers...Or there was a recipe change between 2000 and 2003, or a new brewer revamped the whole operation...3.6/5

2000 bottling, sampled 3/3/04: Pours a deep amber with hints of bergundy. A beautiful frothy head lays atop and carries well. The nose is of dried figs, port, licorice and anise. The initial taste is subdued but overwhelmingly enjoyable. This has aged extremely well. There is no profoundness to the flavor, instead they all just melt across the tongue like the one chord at the finale of Stravinsky's "Le Sacre Du Printemps". As it warms the abv lets its' presence be known, but not disturbingly. This is an amazingly crafted ale that I thank my dear friend Casey for sending me.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2007 2007-09-02, corked bottle, vintage 2001, 6 years old, 8.5% ABV, 7-5-8-3-15=38Not very complex but solid, with a good caramel aroma and flavor, but the bitterness is almost gone. The malt flavor at least doesnt show aging. Interesting.2004-02-27, corked bottle, vintage 2000, 4 years old, 8.5% ABV, 9-5-8-4-16=42Brown color. Very good aroma: malt, candi sugar, oranges and other fruits. Better body structure than the other Gouden Carolus, sweet, initially with caramel, presenting some light liquorice later. Correct, good final.
Dark brown in color, minimal head. Aroma of malts and alcohol.  Dark fruit flavors.  Dry finish.

Don't laugh but my girlfriend who drinks bud enjoyed this one.  I started enjoying this one in 2000.  2003 smelled great.  Pitch black in color with a long lasting head.  Tasted like heaven with awesome malt, caramel, chocolate, plum flavors.  Leaves your palate wanting more with it's good lingering sweet aftertaste.  save it for 5 or 10 years.  Bon anniversaire charles the fifth.

Bottled 2002 vintage: Unclear amber coloured. Beige medium lasting head. Alcahol, fruits and liqourice in the aroma. Alcahol, malt and liquorice in the flaovour. Smooth mouthfeel. Nice alcahol sweetness in the end. Good one.
Pretty good strong malty beer, but the underlying sweetness is cloying and overpowering and makes this less enjoyable to me than the regular Gouden Carolus.

Bottled. Vintage 2000.
Dark redbrown with almost no head. A lot of yeast-particles.
A warm and smooth aroma with juniperberries, prune, plum and menthol.
Soft and velvetly smooth palate.
A very complex flavour with a lot of dried fruits. Mmmmm!

Bottled. Vintage 2000. 
Deep brown colour with a diminishing head. Fantastic velvetty and vineous aroma of dried fruits, prune, plum, menthol...! Flavour of dried fruits, marshmallow-menthol, plum, prune...! Velvetty mouthfeel.

Deep brown/ruby color with a thin head & syrupy body. Slightly vinegary smell.  Good sweet malts with a hint of sourness & acidity.  Roasted malts, caramel & just a bit bitter.  Not quite as good as I expected.

Dense reddish brown apearance, good head formation.Rich, sweet, creamy malt aroma, bready, sweet caramel and alcohol evident. Sweet careamel/cotton candy flavor with licorice and slighlty roasted coffee touches. Plenty of fruitiness to enhance the sweetness but it really dries out well towards the end.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2004 Vintage 2003  Topped by a rocky tan head this clear ruby bodied beer is a sight to behold in my chalice. The aroma is that of plums, sweet caramel, and cherries. The flavor complements the aroma very nicely. There is a bit more of a buttery/woody character in the flavor then the aroma. Immediately after the swallow there is a little bit of an alcohol bite, which then contributes to a pleasant warmness throughout the mouth and throat. The body is medium with a slight stickiness to it. The alcohol flavor lingers a tad too long but overall this is a very nice beer.

2003 batch. Pours a cloudy, dark amber color with a small light tan head.  Aroma is malt, paint thinner, tropical fruits, and banana.  Flavor is very malty and yeasty with some nice dark fruit flavors.  Body is very thick with a surprising quick finish.  The beer grew on me with each sip.  Good stuff.

750 ml. brown, corked and caged bottle. 2003 batch. Poured out a murky, brown color, with a decent tan colored head that faded back to a thick lacing, a rim of foam around the rim, and thick mats of yeast floating in the middle of the beer. Aromas right away are of bananas. Smelled like fresh baked banana bread. Aromas of caramel, malts, and slight aromas of dried fruits. Mostly dates and dried apricots. Bready, yeasty tasting, along with pronounced banana flavors. Strong malty backbone carries this entire beer very well. An excellent example of Belgian beer brewing at it's best.
Thick mouthfeel, but not syrupy. Finishes sweet, and wet, not dry and astringent. I wish I could afford to drink this everyday.
At $7.99 each, I hardly think so.

2003 bottling, Sampled January 2004The cork explodes from the bottle.  A deep ruby color that is topped by a dark tan head.  Aromas of plum, raisin, lots of dark malt aromas, and slight notes of alcohol emanate from my glass.  The taste is rich and sweet with dark fruit (cherry, raisin, and fig) and alcohol in the finish.  The mix of fruit and alcohol is evocative of brandy.  Ends with a bit of acidity, which is a nice balancing note.  The fruitiness is perhaps most reminiscent of dark cherries, though there are some subtle notes of peach as well.  This is quite good, very rich and a definite brew to savor.  Could perhaps use something to balance the sweetness and fruitiness; maybe some Belgian yeast complexity or some off-setting spice notes.  This beer is very smooth, with no harsh components despite the high alcohol.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2010 750cl Corked bottle dated 2002. Label has a blue banner reading "Grand Cru of the Emperor". Poured a hazy firey reddish amber color with a thick head which reduced in size quickly. Aroma is a malty fruity one with notes of caramel and vanilla. Has a sugary brandy like quality as well in the nose. Mouthfeel is full and velvety smooth with a crisp finish that couldnt be better. Flavor is fruity and delicious with sweet candy sugar and yeast creating a complex and flavorful ale. The 2 years of aging has served this ale well. Alcohol is unnoticible and flavors are pronounced and soft. Nice Belgian!2005 vintage  Delicate palate and fruity sweet aromas. Flavor to die for, sweet malty fruity treat for christmas. Cherry, plums, figs and more. My favorite seasonal to be sure!11/7/2010, 2005 Vintage2005 Bottle drinking nicely. What a major difference 5 years make. Ultra smooth and luscious body, no alcohol showing at all. well rounded malt and fruit profile. Faint biterness from long faded hops. Really a great bottle and a fantastic brew for aging.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: 2003 Version: Poured a dark ruby brown with a beutiful beige head. Wonderful aroma of malt, candi sugar, figs and oak.  Nice full mouthfeel with a pleasant malt sweeetness balanced by notes of figs, chocolate, dark fruits, oakiness, and a slight alcohol presence near the finish.  A real treat, I must get another bottle to age.

pungent apple and date aroma, redish purple with a nice thin light khaki head, strong date and ripe fruit flavors, sticky mouthfeel and great body, nutty and molasses flavors with currant notes and a slight sour apple finish

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2003 2003 vintage. Dark ruby color with a big lasting creamy beige head. Sweet candy sugar and wood aroma. Flavor is sweet with maple syrup, toffee, and figs. Alcohol is well hidden. Finish is acidic and dry.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2004 2000 vintage (4 yrs old). Dark brown colour w. very small beige head. Sweet (candi sugar), dark rum/alcohol, little cork, musty cellar-like qualities. Rounded, soft, medium bodied. Very nice..... 2004 vintage: imo more full-flavoured and better... (8,4,8,4,16)
The 2003 version. High in alcohol percentage 10%. Red brown in color with a tan head. Sweet and fruity. Delicious and complex. I really liked it.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2003 The 2003/10% version. Red brown in color with a tan head. Woody fruity aroma with a hint of alcohol. Hops? Sweet big fruity malt flavor with hints of wood. Delicious and complex. Have another bottle aging and can't wait till year next.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Medium bodied brew with a dark slightly hazy hue and little head. The aroma hinted of toasted malt, bourbon chared oak, maple, prune, and alcohol. The taste doesn't match the smell, it's one-diminsional with a malty sweet base and alcohol. Boring and flat.

Dark red-brown with minimal beige head.  Aroma is oh so inviting -- rich, maple sugar sweet, fig, buttery, wood, alcohol.  Taste is disappointing (relative to the aroma) in its overstrong alcohol, but also has some fig and spice.  Quite full body.

Thick mountain malt and alcohol nose.  Figs, dates, cereal, and a good amount of alcohol in the taste.  Really sweet, sugar sticky palate; just coats the mouth.  Like a whiskey barrel aged beer.  Really nicely done.

2003, 10%.  Pretty deep brown with some reddish highlights, long lasting tan head that leaves a great lace.  Aroma of madeira, raisins, smooth toffe malts, and figs. Flavors match the nose, along with hints of tobacco leaf, oak, molasses, and a balancing bitterness. Fantastic beer, must get another bottle for aging.  Just magnificent.

2003 vintage & 10%abv.  
Fig, Dates and raison aroma.  Sweet and overly ripened plums.  Hints of oak.  Smooth, velvety mouthfeel.  Sweet taste echoes the nose, no alcohol detected.  Like a sugary sweet, less complex Terrible.  Long, smooth finish.

Excellent companion while I am smoking my Thanksgiving turkey. The pour is a deep dark tea colored masterpiece with a thick creamy everpresent head with thick lacing. Aroma has essences of chocolate, raisins, and a wee bit of alcohol. The mouthfeel is luxuriant, especially as it warms - just slides off the tongue down the throat. Alcohol is hidden oh so extremely well. Pleasant malty flavor with elements of chocolate, sweet cherries and ripe figs.  Leaves an aftertaste of toffee. Overall an excellent Belgian ale. Would make a great after dinner treat.

A purplish brown color with moderate almond head.  Smells like tequilla and black cherry brandy.  Body is very odd.  Pie crust and mild sour orange.  Gets more acidic with time, like smarties kind of.

2000 vintage, 8% abv.  Fruity, sweet and slightly acetic aroma, featuring notes of red grape, licorice, vanilla, tannic wood, faint banana esters and dark brown sugar.  Deep, dark garnet color with a subsiding head that forms an intricate Mandelbrot pattern.  Flavor profile is sweetly malty, spicy and fruity, with a yeasty, gently warming, lengthy finish.  Vinous, lightly effervescent, syrupy and thin mouthfeel, some acidity that subsides after approaching room temperature.  Recommended, especially to those who have tried and enjoyed the Gouden Carolus Classic.

Pours very dark, a bit hazy. Against the light it has reddish edges. No head on this one really, meaning little to no lace as well. Strong wine like aroma, grapes mostly, maybe more like grape juice than wine as the alcohol is hidden nicely. Caramel compliments the fruit rather well. Many flavors in this one. Starts out a little sharp then branches out into some spices, perhaps a dash of cinnamon, as stated before I find brown sugar, and more caramel. Finish is slightly bitter, with some fruit and an alcohol kick. Nice smooth palate that for all of the sweet flavors isn't too sticky. Nice belgian.

dark n' cloudy with a reddish tint..nice tan head..aroma of brandy with a lime touched tequila essence and maybe a tad of caramel covered apple...apple pie flavors with lots of cinamon, brandy, brown sugar, and caramel..big carbination..full body..brown malty goodness..pretty sweet.
UPDATED: JAN 12, 2007 Dark brown color, slightly cloudy, small head.  Sweet, yeasty, brown sugar aroma.  Flavor is sweet, and full.  Very Good Belguim Strong.

reddish brown color, huge and lasting tan head with tremendous lacing. lots of apple and pear in the aroma also some Nesquik chocolate milk powder. lots of fruit in the flavor, some chocolate and maybe what i perceive as a little roasted character. no alcohol in the aroma, slight hint in the flavor...surprising for 10% ABV.

Sampled at From The Vine monthly beer tasting Oct 13th, 2003: 2003 Bottle: Dark ruby/amber with a medium beige head and nice lacing. Aroma of plum, malt, caramel and banana. Fairly rich and complex with a nice vinous blend of fruit (apple mostly), malt, chocolate and a little alcohol. The finish is sweet and lingering. Definitely worth getting again.

2003 vintage750ml bottle 

Pours a dark ruby with plum highlights topped by a creamy dark tan head with modest retention.  Decent lacing.  The aroma is quite lovely and slowly reveals dark fruits, such as raison and plum, hefty medicinal and clove phenolics, banana and bubblegum esters, caramel, sugar-drenched pineapple, spicy alcohol, and licorice.  The flavor is fairly sweet, with an initial burst of spicy fruit and clove phenolics.  Some banana too.  Moves to an earthy, yeasty character with some licorice and plum, then finishes rustic and slightly musty.  Hint of alcohol on the tail end, but the 10% is well disguised.  Its a bit watery in body, and could use a bit more oomph.  Regardless, this is a good brew and one Id like to try again after a few years of cellaring.

This is a lovely beer, packaged nicely as well. Poure red brown It's tan, dissipating head leaves just a film and hints at the ABV to follow. Malty and syrupy in the nose, with hints of raisin and prune. Medium body, slightly syrupy. Malt is wondefully

Very impressive...something that I have wanted to try for a very long time, but held off because of the price.  A nice winey taste accompanies this one, or perhaps a port, or even a brandy or even a nicely aged scotch.  A lisght achohol burn in the aftertaste, but many, many complexities show up after is it is at room temperature.  Figs, plums, winey and good aged liquor all at the same time.  I really look forwad to trying this again.

Pour generated a small but respectable head, quickly dissipated and left small islands of concentrated foam. Color is dark ruby mahogany, not opaque. No lacing. Aroma has alcohol, port, cherries, nut bread. Flavor has strong alcohol, not subtle, yeasty and carbonated aftertaste has some fresh dark fruits as well. Complex and a little unbalanced with the portish sweet cherry part of this beer. This would age quite well seeing that this is a fairly new bottle. Slightly sweet and bitter with an astringent, alcohol mouthfeel. Very nice overall, I'm glad I could try this.
2003. Dark brown-ruby, sweetish earthy alcohol aroma. Nutty earthy dark fruit tastes prevail. Creamy on the palate. Semi-sweet finish.

[2000 vintage] The aroma is sweet with notes of wood, yeast, plums, apples and other fruits - lovely complex. The color is redbrown but it has no head. The flavor is sweet and fruity and is very powerful - a fine beer.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2004 2001 bottle. The color is dark  amber with a little disappointing head. The tastepattern is a complex mix of fruits, caramel, chocolate and a wide vareity of spices. UPDATE: Had a 2000 bottle, and it was very different, more balanced and   port-like
2003 bottle.  Dark ruby black body.  Raisins, plums and chocolate.  Body is thick and rich, yet also bubbly at the same time.  Absolutely delicious.

Smells like a banana split -- chocolate, vanilla, caramel, banana.  Rich, sweet, sugary flavor,-- warm and bitter on the lips with cocoa and coffee.  Loses carbonation too rapidly with some astringency in the palate.  A very good and fairly balanced brew, in its category.  Beautiful bottle, cap and deep coffee colored brew with good frothy tan head.  It's obvious that this would do well with a couple years' cellaring.

2002 vintage. Beautiful dark reddish brown with generous head. Some sediment. Malt, fruits and toffee in the aroma. Full bodied powerful vinous fruity flavoure with some acidity. Long lasting aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2004 2003, bottle. I enjoyed this very much. A bit of chocolate on the nose and in the taste. It's rather sweet ands somewhat fruity. I will age at least one bottle, since I think this will age very well. 
UPDATE: Tried this on tap at Monk's, and found it to be even sweeter than the bottle version.

Dark red, like blood, with a lush, creamy head.  Smells of honey and vanilla.  A mellow, yet full-flavored beer.  Really refreshing.  Medium alcohol.  A spicy, pleasant lingering of herbs and wine on the palate.  Earthy mild, but clean sweetness.  Crisp.

[2002] (the bottle states 8% abv) This is a very vinous beer, in both aroma and flavor.  Ruby color with a lasting white foamy head - this is very subtle but highly enjoyable - the flavor is a creative mix of aged (oak aged?) red wine and fruity malty sweetness that lingers on the tongue and lips - a mix of mild candies and good wine - how can you loose?

2001 bottle, so over two years old. Has that typical Gouden Carolus aroma and flavors that I love. Mainly banana and vanilla in the aroma. Hazy, redbrown color, beige head, very good lace. Very full, sweet, vanilla, smooth, hops well present. Long lasting finish, sticky with a little alcohol burn.

(draught) Thick yellow/brown head, dissipating. Dark brown beer with a shine of "blood-oranges". Chocolatey nose, dessert wine, very ripe banana. Taste is dry-bitter, underlying dark and caramel malt. Lots of rest-sweetness, some raisins. Full-bodied, dense, oily. Alcoholburn, warming effect. Nice. But an aged bottled one is better.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2006 Rerate: i tasted an aged cuvee vd keizer 2002, conserved by the owner of the Deugniet in den Bosch. Very nicely aged, small hints of port, bit more alcohol burn, full flavored. 
Original rating: Chestnut brown color, short but lasting head. Aroma of roasted malts, bit fruity. Quite sharp taste, bit alcoholic. Roasted malts, not real soft as i hoped for. 3.5

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Rating reflects aged sample. Re-rate: Bottled, 2001 version sampled in 2008, i.e. 7 years old. Still a fair head after all these years, beautiful. Aroma and flavour have aged extremely well, at every sniff i discovered new notes including roasted malts, chocolate, peat, raisins, wood, unbelievable. Everlasting finish in which new flavour arise as well. This beer is truly outstanding in every aspect. Its already very good when fresh, but absolutely outstanding after 7 years of aging, and will probably improve even further when older. Forget about all these imperial stouts, there is nothing like an aged Belgian Strong Ale like this! Original rating: On tap. Brown coloured, beautiful head. Complex malty, fruity nose and flavour. This combination of bittersweet malty flavours with complex fruiteness is exactly what im looking for in a beer. Very good! Rating 4.5
Sorry folks, I can't say this beer lived up to expectations. To me it was sour, too strong and too sharp. But then again, I'm not (yet) in the 100 beer club :-)

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2004 2004 vintage: Pours a similar copper brown with a thick frothy off-white head.  Aroma is full of brandy, sweet Belgian malt and bready yeast.  Flavor is along the same lines.  A very nice and well balanced Belgian brew.

2000 vintage: Aroma boasts caramel, soy, and rum and coke.  Thick sweet syrupy body with some fruity apricot finishes malty and dry with a light alcoholic burn.  Overall smooth, complex, and a fine Belgian strong ale.
Lovely and complex.  This is definitely a beer to have on a clean palate as there is so much going on you won't know where to begin.  In some ways it reminded me of a good glass of whiskey.
wow.  impressive.  there where many flavors going on in this beer.  I liked the full rich variabled flavor,  but i'm still not a belgy

Vintage 2000: Pours a dark, clear, reddish brown color with a small, fizzy tan head that does not linger. The aroma is strong with malts, raisons, bread, bananas, and alcohol. I must admit that the aroma really makes me want to dive into this beer and eat it. Full body with moderate carbonation, the flavor is thick and rich with malts and hints of caramel, chocolate, and banana bread. The finish is sweet, malty, and full of banana flavors with just a tad bit of alcohol. Wow! What a great beer! Smooth and more than delicious, this one is magnificent!
Brown in color.  Nose is of sweet brown sugar and soy sauce and wine notes.  Yeast and quite dominant banana flavors.  Alcohol barely noticeable and well concealed.
Tap, Café Morshuis Albergen. Malty flavor with chocolate and some licorice. The fruitiness of ripe grapes. Excellent beer!

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2003 2000: Dark,burgundian,color with yeast abound,and a lovely head.Aroma is heavily malty-sweet,woody,musty,some good fruity,yeast notes as well.Light carbonation and big body. Dry,vinous,sweet flavors,lead to a musty,sweet finish.Little bit of cardboard in the finish as well,slightest hint of oxidation. Some slight bitterness rounds out this nicely aged,balanced,beer.

2000:  Light plum.  Minimal ring of off-white foam.  Typical Het Anker yeasty bubblegum and licorice nose, with leather, cassis, plum, coconut, black cherry, damp wood, metallic traces, and a fair hint of solvent; vinous tinged.  Light prickly carbonation.  Initial burnt honey flavors are pursued by concord grape, bubblegum, black cherry, light acidity, toffee, caramel, cardboard, wood, cream, apple skins, and plum.  Finishes with mild licorice shades, plum notes, and burnt fig.  Although lacking in appearance and palate, this is up there with the sweeter tinged, more unique belgians.  Would be the perfect accompaniment to a dessert and/or a quality cigar.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: JUN 8, 2003 Walking through an apple orchard carrying bushels of tart green and sweet red apples, bosc pears, yellow bananas, ripe oranges, golden raisins, plums, and massive kiwi.  My slow steps work in concert with my jaw as it finishes a piece of sweet, delightful bubblegum.  The heavens and the sun shine on me as seraphim sing their choruses of delight and pleasure.  As I make my way through the trees, I come to pools of creamy chocolate and caramel.  I lay with a loved one against the trees as we gaze at the suns reflections as it sets.  We delight in feeding each other the luscious fruit dipped in the finest accoutrement.  Alas, as the sun sets on this, another splendid day, I am forced to wait to experience this wondrousness again.  Only once a year does God create his nectar; only once a year is the day of my birth celebratedthis the 24th of February.
2002.  Great ale. Wine(grape), fruity, and malty flavor.  Warming aclcohol and dry finish.  Recommended.

(2002 bottle 8% alc) A deep hazy amber/ruby with lots of slow moving sediment with a nice off white head and lace. Very Ommegang like nose of wine, marshmellow, grains of paradise, anise, banana, raison and more. Medium to thick bodied, creamy with rich flavors of banana, rasion, winey fruit, grains of paradise and cocoa. Finished with a push of lush fruit and a bit of powdery dryness. Very similar to ommegang, a little softer but its strikingly similar IMHO. Number 500:)

2002, Ruddy brown color with a cream colored tight bubbled head.  Aromas of prunes, dates, brown sugar, light anise and hearty malt.  Malt flavors abound.  Toffee, milk chocolate, treacle and plunes all followed by warming alcohol.  Complex, but perhaps a bit to forthright.  A year or two will do this one well.

The beer pours a bemused cherry red color, the head prodigious, creamy in its texture, the lace fine sheets to cling to the glass. Nose is malt, ripe cherry sweet, hints of fusel alcohol, also present to this old nose. Front is sweetly malt; the top is middling in feel. Finish is potently acidic with the hops being apropos to the style, quite dry aftertaste. The high ABV, warms the tummy, and adds that just right character to the beer. I could not wait to sample this beer, but I have two more to age away as recommended. Ranks #222 on my current 1000 beer master list.

This was a very interesting Belgian.  Fruity aroma combined with a dark amber/brown color and off white head.  Taste is a combination of dried fruits and malty sweetness.  Worth finding and enjoying by yourself or in good company.

2000 vintage.

tremendous brew.
dark brown with red highlights
complex aroma of malt, cinnamon, cocoa, coffee and fruit.
taste is equally complex , malty but withg enogh tart and yeasty flavors to keep one guessing- lot of sweet and sour elements, some pear, plums and a smoky burned taste too.
produced and bottled once every year - will have to look for different vintages

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2014 2014 bottle (Brewed 03/03/2014).  Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is hazy dark orange-brown, unfiltered. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie dough, cooked caramel, toasted bread), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with light notes of raisin, overripe banana, orange peel, black cherry, cinnamon, brown sugar, alcohol, hint of peppermint. Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Full body, velvety/creamy texture, lively/soft carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Good year for the Blauw this year, very creamy and nuanced. Hopefully that bodes well for the Rood as well, but havent seen the 2014 of that one in local stores yet.
Its hard to rate this because the bottle I got was flat, and I only drank a little of it. It seemed like a good beer, but I need to try it again.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2007 2001 vintage, sampled 1/2007 - pours a dark reddish-brown colour under a little but stable beige foam; lot of particules floating in the beer; the aroma is richly malty and fruity (figs and plums) with notes of wood; quite a lot of sweetness, slightöy madeirized, full and regular malt body; the finish is long and malty with more notes of dark fruits, some candi sugar and a touch of warming alcohol down the throat - very good though Im not sure ageing improved it, on the contrary
